Shortage of Corn.See Latest Intelligence.RUSSIA.Note from M. Trotsky. Sir G. Buchanan telegraphed on the 21st November [No. 1845] the following literal translation of an official note issued by M. Trotsky: I have the honour to inform you that the National Congress of Councils of Workmen and Soldiers' Deputies established on the 26th October, old style, a new Government of the Russian Republic under the form of a Council of Commissioners of the Beople. The president of this Government is M. Lenin, and the direction of foreign policy was entrusted to me [M. Trotsky] as the People's Commissary for Foreign Affairs. I have the honour to draw your attention to the text of the Gazette for the armistice and democratic peace, without annexations or contributions, founded on the right of peoples to dispose of themselves a proposal approved by the assembled Councils of Workmen and Soldiers and to pray your Excellency to regard the above-mentioned document as a formal proposition of an immediate armistice on all fronts, and for the opening without delay of the peace negotiations proposal which the plenipotentiary of the Government of the Russian Republic is addressing simultaneously to all belligerent nations and their Governments.In regard to this on the 24th November Sir G. Buchanan telegraphed [No. 1863] that the following note had been addressed to the Norwegian, Dutch, Spanish, Swiss',. Danish, and Swedish Ministers by M. Trotsky in his official capacity as People's Commissioner for Foreign Affairs: " On the 8th/21st November, according to the decision taken by the Congress of Soviets of Workmen and Soldiers' Deputies I addressed, in the name of the Council of People's Commissioners, to allied embassies a proposal for the commencement of negotiations, an immediate armistice on all fronts, and a democratic peace, without annexation or contribution, based on the will of the people. Simultaneously the Council of People's Commissioners instructed the military authorities, delegates of the republican army, to commence the preliminary negotiations with the military authorities of the hostile armies for an immediate armistice on our own and on all fronts." Informing, you as above, i have the honour to beg you to take all steps to communicate officially to the enemy Government our proposals for an immediate[898-71] B armistice a,nd for the commencement of peace negotiations. At the same time I permit myself to express the hope that you will take all steps in your power to acquaint, with all necessary fullness, the public opinion of the country by which you are accredited....." The labouring masses of neutral, countries are suffering the greatest misery, the result of this criminal slaughter which, unless it is ended, threatens also to engulf the peoples still remaining outside the war.....The Government therefore rely onfinding the fullest support in the labouring masses' of neutral countries in the struggle for peace, and beg you accept the assurance of the readiness of the Russian democracy to strengthen and develop the friendliest relations with the democracy of all countries."Instructions for the commander-in-Ghief.-On the 22nd November he transmitted [No. 1848] the text of the instructions telegraphed to the Russian Commander-in-Ohief: The Council of People's Commissioners, 'under instructions from All-Russian Congress of Workmen and Soldiers' Deputies, has assumed authority and at the same time undertaken to propose to all belligerent peoples and their Governments an immediate armistice on all fronts and the immediate opening of negotiations with a view to the conclusion of peace on democratic principles. Now, when the authority of the Soviet has been secured at all the most important points of the country, the Council of People's Commissioners considers it necessary at once to make a formal proposal for an armistice to all belligerents, both to allies and to those in hostile relations with us. A similar statement has been sent by the People's Commissioner for Foreign Affairs to all official representatives of the allied countries in Petrograd. You, citizen Commander-in-Chief, are instructed by the Council of the People's Commissioners, in execution of the decision taken by the All-Russian' Congress of Soviets of Workmen's and Soldiers' Deputies immediately on receipt of the present instructions, to address yourself to the military authorities of the enemy armies with a proposal for the immediate cessation of military operations, with a view to the opening of peace negotiations. Entrusting you to conduct these preliminary negotiations, the Council of the People's Commissioners orders you, first, to keep the Soviet constantly informed by telegraph of the course of your negotiations with representatives of enemy armies; and, secondly, to sign an armistice only after it has been approved by the Council of the People's Commissioners. (Signed) Lenin, Trotsky, Krilenko.Soviet Proclamation to the Army. On the 25th November he telegraphed [No. 1868] that the official Soviet paper had published a proclamation to all regiments, divisions, corps, and army committees signed by M. Trotsky, dated 6 A.M., 24th November. He alluded to the written protest made by the allied military repre-sentatives at general headquarters against the conclusion of a separate armistice when their Governments had made no reply to the proposal put forward by the present Russian Government for a general armistice on all fronts. He characterised the note as an attempt by the allied representatives to force by threats the Russian army and people to continue the war in accordance with treaties made by the old regime, which had been condemned by the present G-overnment as no longer binding. He said : " Soldiers, workmen, peasants ! Your Soviet will not permit the foreign bourgeoisie, to whip you back to the slaughterhouse. Let them all learn that the soldiers, workmen, and peasants of Russia did not overthrow the Emperor and the Government of Kerensky in order to remain cannon fodder for ally imperialists." Sir G. Buchanan adds that as soon as he heard of this lie sent the military attache to protest, through the ministry of war, against the proclamation as likely, in the excited state of the public mind, to endanger the lives of allied representatives at the front.Statement of Situation made by M. Trotsky. On the 22nd November he telegraphed [No. 1850 J the following summary of a statement respecting BusskVs foreign relations made by M. Trotsky in his capacity of people's commissioner for foreign affairs at a sitting of the central executive committee of the Congress of Workmen and Soldiers' Deputies held on the 21st November. M. Trotsky began by stating that the foreign policy of the new Government had passed a decree respecting peace, as approved by the All-Russian Congress of Sovyets. The bourgeoisie of the allied countries, he declared bitterly, in common with all Europe, had at first been hostile to the decree, and had failed to recognise the decree, not as a mere party statement, but as a formal proposal by a Government representing millions. Theinternal political situation created by the events of 8th November had hitherto prevented the new administration from making formal peace proposals in the recognised procedure through the accredited foreign representatives in Russia. But it must now be patent to all that the new authority is a real one and must be accepted.As to the attitude of the Allies towards peace and the new Government, he stated that the British Government was probably most hostilely disposed, since England stood to lose the least and win the most from the war. France had suffered most, and was pacifically inclined, but her sympathy towards the Government was tempered by mistrust of its relations with Germany. The feeling against the war was daily growing amongst the French proletariat; Italy had welcomed the change in Russia with enthusiasm. The attitude of America would probably be the most tolerant of all the Allies, since the exhausted condition of Europe must be to her advantage, and the American capitalists who drove her into war were desirous to invest their millions in Russia. As regarded Germany her internal, economic condition was compelling her to adopt a semi-acquiescent attitude towards Russia, and German peace proposals were mainly dictated by a desire to transfer to her opponents the responsibility of the prolongation of the war.The actual reception of Russians peace decree among the proletariat of all Europe, including Germany, had exceeded the most optimistic expectations; they understood that the change of authority was effected not merely as a seizure of power by a band of conspirators supported by workmen, guards, and sailors, as alleged by our opponents, but was the commencement of a universal movement which would open a new epoch in the history of the world. M. Trotsky declared that the war had received its death-blow, and that European Governments had already abandoned all idea of the realisation of the original aims for which war was undertaken, and were now engaged in endeavouring to liquidate the venture with the least loss to themselves.Referring to the previous declaration of his intention to publish all secret inter-national agreements, M. Trotsky stated he had now obtained possession of all official documents, which he described as masterpieces of cynicism, and stated he would publish them in the immediate future. He added that they consisted not of formal treaties, but of diplomatic correspondence and cypher telegrams exchanged between Governments,Publication of Secret Documents. On the 23rd November Sir G. Buchanan telegraphed again [No. 1857] saying that the first instalment of the secret correspondence which M. Trotsky had found at Ministry for Foreign Affairs had been published in the press.The correspondence, of which translations were being forwarded, comprised the following: Telegrams addressed to Russian representatives abroad in 191,), regarding the agreements respecting Constantinople and the Straits, and mentioning our special interests in Persia and Asia Minor. Telegram addressed to the Russian representatives in Paris in March 1916 defining the Russian attitude at forthcoming conference. Principal points are the free action of France and Great Britain in regard to the western frontiers of Germany in return for the equality provided for Russia in regard to the eastern (group undecypherable) and purely Russian character of the Polish question. Telegrams to and from Paris in February 1917 agreeing to the proposals ofM. Doumergue regarding left bank of the Rhine. Telegrams from Ter.....on theinternal situation in Bussia and on the collective representations made by the three Ambassadors on the 9r.fi October. In one of these he expresses his (? thanks) to Mr. Lansing for the non-participation of the United States Ambassador. Telegram from the Russian Charge d'Affaires at Berne, dated the 9th October last, reporting a meeting of German and French financiers who are supposed to have discussed terms of peace at the expense of Russia. The telegram adds that the English denied having taken part, but that Mr. Bell, of Lloyd's Bank, had arrived in Geneva on the 15th September.There appeared to be nothing in the correspondence which discredited the Allied Governments.An Opinion on the Situation. Telegraphing again on the 25th November, Sir G. Buchanan transmitted [No. 1864] a message from the military attache saying that a prominent personage with whom he had spoken attributed the late fiasco entirely to M. Kerensky, by whose vacillation all the reliable elements of the population had been alienated ; as an example of this he mentioned that M. Kerensky had dashed, in his car, between the Cossacks and the Bolsheviks,, whom the former were nbout to attack and would certainly have driven out of Tsarkoe-Selo, and as usual made a speech with the [898-71] B 2 result that the two parties fraternised. The military attaches informant thought that there would be a straight fight between the Bolshevik and bourgeois parties : he believed in the Don party, and hoped that Korniloff might be induced to escape (he had so far refused), as he was a better leader of men than Kalediu. Cutting off supplies was all that the Don party could do, and this would mean the starvation of the army on the Western front.Situation in Archangel. -The consul at Archangel telegraphed on the 22nd November [No. 48] that the situation in that place continued to be almost normal and the leaderg of all parties were so far on the side of order. Local conditions were favourable to the maintenance of this satisfactory situation, but the question of food and clothing would undoubtedly be the most important if not the decisive factor,, and the outlook in this regard was hardly so satisfactory.The Germans in Courland. Sir H. Rumbold telegraphed on the 26th November [No. 1147 j that the Germans, in order to create a feeling in favour of Germany, were conducting a systematic propaganda in Courland and spending enormous sums of money. They seemed to be preparing the way for a plebiscite with a view to the establishment of an "independent" Courland. This information had been acquired from a direct and absolutely sure source by one of his colleagues.POLAND.The Activist Parties. Sir E. Howard telegraphed on the 24th November [No. 3294] that the " Affconbladet " of that day had stated that the Warsaw Press had announced that a deputation of the Polish Activist parties, with two representatives of each party, would start shortly for Berlin and Vienna in order to enter into closer relations with the German and Austro-Hungarian parliamentarians at their conference. The deputation would also be instructed to give information regarding the Polish internal situation. The names of the members of the deputation included Zorewski Ronickier, of the Central National party, of which Prince Alexander Lubecki was head.TURKEY.Conference a.t Berne. Mr. Balfour telegraphed to Lord Bertie on the 26th November [No. 2830] instructing him to inform the French Government that the objects which His Majesty's Government desired, to obtain at the conference with the Turkish delegates at Berne were : (a) An improvement in the treatment of British prisoners of war in Turkey ; (b) An exchange of invalid combatant prisoners of war; (c) The exchange of civilians including French civilians if, as we understand, the French Government have no objection. He added that the results of the conference would be communicated to the French Government without delay.German Support of Pan-Turanianism. An agent calls attention to the fact that the German Government has for some time past in Turkey been encouraging the formation of Turanian clubs, formed expressly to inculcate the belief that every effort must be made by Moslems to constitute, a Moslem empire stretching from the Mediter-ranean to China. This was being taught in schools and universities, and the most suitable converts were sent to Russian Moslem countries for propaganda work. The movement was apparently spreading. Germany was said to be spending millions on this work, and Turks and Russian Moslems were' being taught to believe that a hom;)geneous Moslem empire would eventually lead to Afghanistan and India through Central Asia-of course under the protection of Germany.PALESTINE.The German Zionist Press. - Reuter's agent telegraphed from Amsterdam on the 26th NovemU-T that the Jiidische Rundschau, the organ of the Zionist Association in Germany, discussing the British Governments declaration regarding the creation of a home in Palestine fur the Jewish people, says: -" It is a mistake to regard to regard the British assurance as bluff, for if Great Britain succeeded in occupying Palestine she would be immediately obliged to fulfil the promises given in the declaration. -Moreover, it is impossible to doubt that Great Britaiifs allies have agreed to meet Zionist wishes. A final solution, however, will only be possible at the peace congress." 1 . The journal appears to regard it as necessary to get the assent of Turkey and the I Central Powers for the realisation of such a Zionist scheme.The Kolnische Volks-Zeitung, commenting on this statement, says : "The Central Powers regard these desires with good-will on the understand-ing, of course, that Palestine remains a component part of a strong and secure Turkish Empire, and offers all religions the same freedom."["The Times," 27th November, 1917.] .Persecution of the Jews. Statements made by prisoners taken on the Palestine i front suggest that there has been a good deal of persecution of the Jews on the part of the Turks.PERSIA.A New Cabinet. Sir C. Marling telegraphed on the 24th November [No. 401] that a new Cabinet had been formed by Ain-ed-Dowleh with Mukhbares-Sultaneh as Minister of Justice, Mushar-ul-Mulk as Minister of Finance, Amin-al-Mulk as Minister of Posts, and Vossuk-ed-Dowleh as Minister of Education ; the other office-holders being as before. The Shah exercised the strongest pressure on Vossuk-ed-Dowleh to induce him to accept office ; and it is generally expected that he will be asked to form a Cabinet in the immediate future, the present extraordinary combination, which implies no change of policy, being due mainly to the Shab's dislike to abrupt transit. The inclusion of the new Minister of Justice is none the less an offence that it will probably be explained as a set-off to the Minister of Education.Shortage of Com. Sir C. Marling telegraphed on tins 23rd November [No. 399] that the consul at Shiraz had informed him that grain only existed in small quantities and had to be brought from great distances. Hence the high prices. As far as possible prices had been regulated, and more drastic action would lead to trouble. Flour from India was anxiously awaited, but the 1,000 tons promised had not yet been despatched.LATEST INTELLIGENCE.RUSSIA.Negotiations for an Armistice. Sir G. Buchanan telegraphed on the 28th November [No. 1887 I that an official announcement had been that day published by the Minister of War and the supreme commander-in-chief of the present administration, Krillenko, stating that under his instructions on the afternoon of the 26th November a truce party entered the German trenches, opposite that portion of the line held by 5th Army, with a proposal to open negotiations for an immediate armistice on all fronts of all belligerents, with a view to the commencement of peace negotiations. A favourable reply was received by the evening of the following day from the German commander-in-chief of the northern front, acting under instructions from German Government ; negotiations are to begin on the 1st December, new style. The communique further stated that this date had been fixed to allow time for the issue of a second invitation to the Allies to accept the Russian peace platform and to act conjointly with the Russians for the conclusion of an armistice.Russians Interned in England. Sir G. Buchanan telegraphed on the 26th November [No. 1874J that he had received a note from M. Trotsky stating that among the foreigners interned in England were two Russians, named Chichirin and Impliroff, who were well known in Russia as "stainless, self-sncrificing men of high ideals who were quite above suspicion." They had, the note stated, provoked the British authorities by upholding the principles of international socialism, as had been done by Maclean in Scotland and by Liebknecbt in Germany. If the British authorities considered such activities to be inadmissible in Great Britain, the Government of the republic must ask for the release of these persons and of others similarly placed in order" -that they might return. The note drew his attention to the fact that in Russia there were many English who made no attempt to conceal their counter-revolutionary attitude and their openly engaging in political activities with counter-revolutionary elements of the bourgeois classes. Public opinion in revolutionary democratic Russia could not accept the position that heroes of the revolution should languish in concentration camps in England whilst British counter-revolutionaries suftered no hardships in Russia. The note concluded by expressing the conviction that this urgent request would meet with the fullest sympathy from the freedom-loving proletariat of Great Britain.In regard to the demand for the release of the two men mentioned above, Mr. Babour instructed Sir G. Buchanan TNo. 2374] to make no reply.The Ukraine.The Ukraine Republic. -The consul at Odessa telegraphed on the 14th November [No. 143] that he had had an interview with the president of the district Bada, who had told him that the Ukraine wanted to return to its position of two and a-half centuries ago by becoming an autonomous State. They wanted to form part of the federal States of Bussia; but they did not want to be dictated to by the Russian Assembly, and therefore, in order to settle the main policy and form a Government, they wished to convene the Ukraine Constituent Assembly before the Russian Assembly met. They desired a common currency, common railways, and a common external policy exclusive of the question of peace and war.On the following" day he telegraphed again [No. 144] sajdng that on the previous evening the local Rada had announced that full power over the ethnographic territory of Ukraine had been assumed by the central Rada at Kieff, and on the 21st November he telegraphed again [No. 150] that he had been informed by the Chief of the Staff that, whilst not separating from the Russian Republic, the Ukraine had declared a " National B,epublic" of its own.PALESTINE.Zionism.Attitude of the Salonica Jews. Mr. Wratislaw telegraphed from Salonica on the 23rd November [No. 164] that the committee of the Jewish Congress of Salonica had requested that a message, of which the following is a translation, might be communicated to the Prime Minister : The committee of the Salonica Jewish Congress received with unspeakable joy the news of the declaration made by the British Government regarding the constitution of the Jewish nation in Palestine, and is greatly moved at the sight of so striking a confirmation of the national aspirations of the Jewish people as that which has been now given by the great and liberal English nation. The Israelites of Salonica, in common with the whole of Jewry, express their deep gratitude to the British Government, with warm hopes for the final triumph of right, of justice, and of that principle of nationality which has been so powerfully defended by England her allies.Scandinavian Zionist Association. Sir Esme Howard telegraphed on the 27th November [No. 3307] that the press had reported that, in connection with the announcement of the British Government regarding Jewish settlement in Palestine, the Scandinavian Zionist Association had held a crowded meeting in Stockholm on the 25th November, at which an expression of lively satisfaction at the announcement had been enthusiastically applauded. A resolution was passed unanimously welcoming the action of the British Government and binding ali present to use every effort to secure a national future for the Jewish people.PaafTKD AT THE KOEKIGN OFFICE BT c. In 1909 the Moslem Ecclesiastical Court of Orenburg, an official body which, under the Old Regime, exercised authority over the Moslems of the Russian Empire, excluding the Caucasus, Crimea and Central Asiatic provinces, and which, among other duties, kept a record of births and deaths, estimated the number of Moslems under its jurisdiction at 5,283,618. This is more than a million in excess of the figures given above for the Kazan, Astrakhan, and West Siberian Tatars, Chuvashes and Bashkirs combined. The difference is probably accounted for by the inclusion of certain sections of the Kirghiz, whose territory is reckoned administratively as part of European Russia. THE PAN-TURANIAN MOVEMENT.1. Origin of the name "Pan-Turanian."Turan is a Persian word. In Persian medieval poetry Si means the steppes and deserts of Central Asia, in contrast to the. settled country of Iran or Persia. The " people of Turan " are the nomads (of many different languages ancl races) who constantly overran Persia from the north-east, till the Russians pacified Central Asia half a century ago.Nineteenth-century philologists in Europe appropriated the . name Turanian for the languages of north-eastern Europe and Asia which are " agglutinative" in structure, in contrast to the Indo-European family. It was really a negative term a pro-visional label for an unexplored mass. " Turanian " research was first taken up seriously by the Magyars, who speak one of these agglutinative languages (of the TJgro-Einnic group) and have always felt themselves isolated among the Latin, Slavonic, and Teutonic speaking peoples of Europe. A medieval Plungarian monk once made a pilgrimage eastward to discover his lost kinsmen, and lighted upon the Bashkirs of the Ural Region; and during the present war Magyar professors are said to bave conducted a propaganda among Russian prisoners of war belonging to easterly Einnish tribes, to prove to them that the Magyars are their brethren and Buda-Best their cultural home.Magyar Ban-Turanianism has followed in the wake of Russian Pan-Slavism. When the Prussians remembered their kinship with the Balkan Slavs, and this movement took on a political form, the Magyars looked about for " Turanian" anti-Slav allies, and naturally thought of the Turks. The famous Hungarian savant, Vambery, was led by this Turanian idea to research among the Turkish-speaking peoples of Central Asia, but the Magyars addressed themselves chiefly to the Osmanlis. When the Magyar struggle for independence in 1848 was crushed by the combined Austro-Russian armies, many leading Magyar refugees had found an asylum at Constantinople. In 1867 these exiles returned to Hungary and became a power in the newly-constituted Bual Monarchy. During the Balkan upheavals of 1875-8 the Magyars were violently pro-Ottoman, and a deputation of Magyar students presented a sword of honour to the Sultan during the Serbo-Turkish War.This Magyar-Ottoman rapprochement was not really racial but political. It rested not on a common consciousness of " Turanianism" but on a common hostility to certain Slavonic States. The same political motives have led people in Bulgaria to accept the Turanian label since the Bulgarian Governments intervention against Serbia and Russia in the European War. Yet the Bulgars are as much Slavs as any other Slavonic-speaking people. The original founders of the Bulgarian State, thirteen centuries ago, Avere certainly " Turanian" nomads from the steppes, but they have left less trace on the Slavs upon whom they imposed themselves in the Balkan Peninsula than the Normans have oil the people of England. Modern Bulgaria is a Slavonic State which has played for its own hand in defiance of Pan-Slav sentiment, ancl wishes for new sentimental catchwords that conform with its Real-Politik.Thus Pan-Turanianism, in its origin, is (a) artificial, and ip) European. The Osmanlis did not extract it for themselves from Persian literature (though they study Persian as we study the Greek and Latin classics); it was offered to them from Europe, and they have not been the wooers but the wooed. The Osmanli has no genuine sentiment for the Bulgar or the Magyar, who are both ex-subjects of his, like the Serb and the Greek. If supposeda 2 self-interest induces the Bulgar and Magyar to fight his battles, subscribe to his loans, give his young men technical instruction, and supply him with machinery, he will take fall advantage of their services. But he feels no more kinship with them than with the other Christian nations of Europe';* and his principal object iw this war is to rid the Ottoman Empire of external European influences, whether these are " Central " or "Entente," " Turanian " or " Teutonic.'-'2. Pan-Turanianism as Pan-Turkism.A trained philologist may be conscious of some unity of structure in all Turanian languages as contrasted with the Indo-European family, but to the uninitiated Osmanli there is no visible relation between his own language, which belongs to the Turkish group, and Magyar, which is TJgro-Einnic. On the other hand, the relation of the various Turkish dialects to one another is obvious to anyone. It can he seen on the map in the names of rivers, mountains, and towns. The Turkish-speaking peoples stretch from Turkey-in-Europe through Anatolia, Trans-Caucasia, Northern Persia and Afghanistan, to Russian Central Asia and Chinese Turkestan, and, in a more broken chain, round the northern shores of the Black - Sea, through Bulgaria, Dohrudja, Crimea, the volga provinces and Siberia, to the neighbourhood of the Arctic Ocean.f They cover an even more extensive though less compact area than the Slavs, and the different Turkish dialects are as readily intelligible to all Turks as the different Slavonic languages are to any speaker of one of them. It was therefore only natural that as soon as the Ottoman Turks became linguisti-cally conscious of their nationality, they should become conscious at the same time of their affinities with other Turkish-speaking peoples, just as the national revival of the separate Slavonic populations produced a common sense of Pan-Slavism among them.Pan-Turanianism, then, in the sense of a Pan-Turkish move-merit originating among the Ottoman Turks, is part and parcel of Ottoman Turkish nationalism, and can only be understood in relation to it.3. Turkish Nationality in the Ottoman Empire.The consciousness of nationality, like the word " Pan-Turanian," has come to the Osmanlis from Europe. The Ottoman Empire began as the very opposite of a national state. It is not called after any people .who inhabit it, but after the prince who founded it Osman. It is true that Osman and his tribe were Turks, hut they were only one out of a dozen Turkish states in Anatolia, and their Turkish neighbours were their worst rivals and enemies. They built up their power by conquests in Europe. Their best taxpayers were Christian subjects, their standing-army Christian converts, their most loyal supporters apostate Albanians and Slavs, who changed their religion but kept their language. They are an Iranian people, speaking dialects of Persian, and their original home is in the mountain ranges which separate the plateau of Persia from the basin of Mesopotamia. South-eastward they are adjoined by kindred mountain populations the Lurs and Bakhfciaris and their expansion has been principally in the opposite, or north-westerly, direction.This expansion has been closely connected with the Turkish migrations. When the Turks made their way from Central Asia into Northern Persia, in the 11th century A.D.,'they did not dislodge the Kurds, who had occu-pied the western ramparts of the Persian plateau for about 3,000 years. They avoided the Kurdish mountains, and turned northwards into Azer-baijan, up the valley of the Araxes, and so into Armenia and Anatolia by a route that left Kurdistan untouched. Anatolia was their goal and Armenia their high road, with the result that, after migrations which went on intermittently for five centuries, Anatolia had become the seat of a new Turkish nation, while Armenia was left depopulated and half desolate. This was the Kurds' opportunity. Kurdish tribes drifted into the vacuum which the Turks had made ; and they have gradually spread over the lake country of Urmia and Van, and the upper valleys of the Tigris and Euphrates, till they have come almost within sight of the Black Sea and the Mediterranean.Prom the point of view of " Pan-Turanian " geography, they have thus possessed themselves of a strategical position. HEJAZ AND EGYPT.The history of Hejaz, since the expansion of Islam established it in the \world's eye, has been governed by the fact that it can neither finance nor feed itself. The primitive economic, difficulties of the towns, Mecca, Medina, Jiddah, Yambo, etc., as well as of the rural districts, settled and un-settled, were aggravated as Hejaz gradually developed into a goal of pilgrimage from all parts of the East, the pilgrims including a large proportion of persons whose demands were on a higher plane of civilization. Though the hay brought money into the country, at the same time it compelled expenditure on the safeguarding and watering of routes, on accommodation, on entertainment, on upkeep and embellishment of holy places and on many other accounts, which taken together went beyond native means: ancl, although food caravans usually accompanied the pilgrims, these did not bring nearly enough for the whole sojourn, which often extended to months. Taif can supply Mecca, in a certain measure, with vegetables, fruit and meat, but the Holy City itself has no grazing anywhere near it for a considerable head of livestock, and none but isolated patches of lean corn dand. Medina is the only district in Hejaz, which produces any surplus of dates, and its crop is uncertain. Roundly it may be said that Hejaz, as a whole, has never been able to supply its local needs with either cereals or pastoral products ; that its chief cities, since they became places of pilgrimage, have depended on external subsidies for their municipal expenditure, and have not contributed to general revenue ; that nothing to speak of can be raised from the rural Hejaz population without causing it forthwith to cease producing its own food ; and that the indirect revenue to be derived from customs duties has never proved enough to offset the extraordinary administrative expenses involved by the pilgrimage. Nor have the resources of the contiguous and neiffhbourin"- districts of Arabia, ever been of a kind or a measure to make good the deficiencies of Hejaz. In the way of food, Qasim sends it butter, and the Ateibah steppe, mutton ; but their moderate supplies are subject to much fluctuation through droughts and insecurity of transit. The Asir Tihamab has, in a good year, a little wheat, maize and millet to spare. More than one attempt has been made by Emirs of Mecca in the past to exploit the resources of the Yemen on behalf of Hejaz. These efforts have never come to anything, not so much because the caravan roads are very long, arduous and perilous, as because Yemen has next to no foodstuffs to spare. With coffee and kat cultivation to maintain, its comparatively dense popula-tion grows no more cereals, and keeps no more livestock, than suffice to feed itself. Yemen exports neither corn nor cattle worth reckoning in consular trade reports.Hejaz, therefore, for the last ten centuries at any rate, has had to depend on external purveyors, who, inevitably have become external protectors ; and of. such the successive lords of Egypt have filled the part during almost the whole period from the dynasty of the Tuhmids to that of Mohammed Ali. It was so as early as the tenth century. Snouck-Hurgronje, the most competent European historian of Hejaz, writes (Mekka I. p. 54) : "In the year 969, as the chronicles tell us, the Fatimites acquired at a great price first place in the Pilgrimage to the exclusion of the Ahbasids, and ever since then the honour of mention in the Friday prayer has gone to the highest bidder... ' Hejaz is always dependent on Egypt for its means of life' wrote a geographer (Mokadassi) a few years later ; and if the Nile flood did not reach its accustomed height, Mecca went hungry for a year."Whoever possessed himself of Egypt, conquered, ipso facto, Hejaz Saladin first, then the Mamelukes, then the Circassian Sultans, and finally the Ottoman Turks. The lord of the Nile for the time being needed no more display of armed force, than usually escorted the Mahmal, to assert himself in Mecca. He held the key of the larder and that was enough. The sub-servience of the Grand Sherifs left little to be desired for many centuries. The)' professed Shiah tenets wdth the first Fatimites, and proclaimed their faith in the Caliph Hakim. When Selim "the Grim" sent to claim the dependencies of Egypt, they were as good Sunnis as any Turk. Their subsequent access of independence in the eighteenth century was independence not of Egyptian supplies, but of political control, while anarchy reigned, on the Nile and dry rot on the Bosphorus. The moment Egypt passed once more under a. single strong ruler Hejaz came obediently to heel the more readily for having experienced, during a decade of Wihabite supremacy, what it is to hanker after fiesh-pOts.It is only since the middle of the nineteenth century that this economic, ancl consequently political, bond has been somewhat relaxed. With the opening of the overland route ancl the frequentation of the lied Sea by steam craft, the Indian granary entered into more serious competition with the Egyptian than theretofore, and by 18.58 Indian traders had grown numerous enough at Jiddah to bring about our first armed intervention in Hejaz affairs. At the same time the Porte, seeing Egypt slipping ever more and more out of its control, initiated a policy designed to knit Hejaz and the other Arabian provinces directly to Constantinople a. policy which was to lead ultimately to the construction of the Hejaz railway. Symptoms of this policy were drastic interference in the succession of the Sherifate, the reigning house being dispossessed twice, in 1851 ancl 1880, by Ottoman mandate ; increase of the Hejaz garrisons ; energetic measures taken in regard to Yemen from 1870 onwards, and in regard to Hejaz by Othman Pasha in the eighties ; and, as important as any, Midhat's occupation of Hasa. in 1871. This last step was only part of what was planned, for the subjugation of Nejd had been hoped for ; but even so, it gave the Turks command of the ports, including Koweit, by which Iraq supplies enter central Arabia. Thus established more firmly on both sides of the Arabian peninsula, Turkey made tentative efforts to compete with Egypt in the supplying of Hejaz. The caravan track from Damascus was garrisoned more efficiently, and surra to the tribes along it "was increased and regularly paid. With the opening of the Suez Canal, the way lay open for steamers, mostly manned by Anatolian Greeks, but sailing under the Turkish flag, to transport the products of Anatolia and Syria to Red Sea ports ; and, by an understanding arrived at with the Emir Mohammed ibn Rashid in the eighties, caravan traffic from Iraq and the Gulf, via Hail or Qasim, to Hejaz was encouraged. In 1903 the Hejaz railway was begun ; by 1908 it was complete to Medina ; and in two years more, bttt for difficulties of terrain, reinforced by strenuous opposition from the Harb, whom the Grand Sherif was covertly supporting, it would have reached Mecca, and continued on its way towards Qunfudah and the Yemen.Such Ottoman measures, however, have had but little effect. Mecca is still nearly 300 miles from railhead by difficult and dangerous roads, and consignments to Medina from the productive Syrian area compete, in cost, with those from Egypt and the Sudan no better than consignments from Iraq compete in speed of transit. Transport even by sea from the Levant is at a, great disadvantage with that from Suez and Port Sudan by reason of greater coal consumption and the burden of Canal dues. The only possible rival of Egypt in the Jiddah food market is India, handicapped by distance, if till the last two years somewhat favoured by rail and port facilities. Moreover, at best, she can be an economic rival only, not a political one.We have changed the political status of Hejaz, but neither we, nor any others, have changed its economic status. Someone outside must still pay for its government and provide its food. If the former need is arranged for we may be easy about the latter. Egypt, the Sudan and India, will meet it in the future as in the past. But who shall finance Hejaz ? Even if the new Kingdom should be stretched to include some considerable part of Syria, it could not expect to get its expenses of administration out of that country. Syria is rich only by a moderate standard, and for long enough to come it will need for itself every piastre it can raise. In the still less probable event of Iraq joining up with Hejaz, it will be in scarcely better position, to help. It has its own ruined house to set in order.This being so, there remain some four possible alternative sources of the necessary financial grants-in-aid. (1) Efkaf properties ? This means has actually been put forward as a practical proposition. But most of the richer vahufs are situated iii what, iu all likelihood, will still he Turkey after this war, and valcufs have first charges on them for the upkeep of mosques, schools, medresschs, fountains and what not. Moreover the sum required by a free Kingdom of Hejaz will be much in excess of the total of the Ottoman surra allowances, which used to be charged on efkaf properties in Turke)- sequestered by Mahmud IT. (2) '" Peter's Pence " from the Faithful all over the Avorld ? Well one would be sorry to be King Husein's Chancellor of the Exchequer, introducing a Budget framed on estimated receipts from that source ! (3) Christian Powers ? If any of these should finance the Kingdom of Hejaz openly and directly, when there is no longer war for an excuse, that kingdom will fall into such discredit in Moslem eyes that it will cease to be worth financing at all. (4) Some external Moslem state or states ? Which of these can be conceived able and willing after the settlement of the present war? Certainly none of those that will preserve independence. And of the others is there any but Egypt that could do it ? The argument, therefore, leads us back to something not unlike, in fact, the status quo ante 1850, by whatever name it shall come to be called in, say, 1918.D.G.H.IDRISI'S OFFENSIVE.In our issue, No. til, p. 365, we printed a statement about agreements reported by Idrisi to have been made between him and certain Yemen elements, including Hashid and Bekil tribesmen, for a combined offensive, ostensibly against the Turkish garrisons in the Yemenite Tihamah and northern highlands. NOTES.Hejaz Railway, Abu Naam to Bowat.Our railway route report is so deficient in detail south of el-Ala, that all and any information about the track thence to Medina is welcome. Lieut. N. W. Clayton, M.C., who has been attached till lately to Sherif Abdullah's. army, has visited the line on various occasions between the Wadi Hamdh bridge, just north of Abu Naam station, and a, point north, but within sight, of Bowat a stretch of about seventy-one kilometres, or rather under forty-five miles. He sends, under date October ,9, some notes.The main bridge crosses Wadi Hamdh, which has been ascending parallel with the line from Jedahah, about one and a quarter miles north of Abu Naam. This bridge is of solid masonry with fourteen arches, twelve to fifteen feet in height. Just north of it, where the mountains come down close to the rails on the east, is a Turkish post with entrenchments, sanyars, and sand-bagged huts. South of it the line passes over three culverts, the first of three arches, the second of four and the third of three (square-topped), before reaching Abu Naam, where a fresh block of hills, behind which Wadi Hamdh bears away from the track, approaches on the east. The line makes a considerable south-westward curve between the main bridge and the station.From Abu Naam the south-westward direction is maintained -for some two and a half miles to a point known as el-Magrah, whence the line turns south along the bottom of a shallow valley averaging seven to eight miles in breadth. The slope on either hand towards the distant hills is very gradual hut steepest on the east. The level is broken only by a few stony undulations a few feet high, until after Stabl Antar station is passed. Just south of this point the foothills of Jebel Antar on the west approach within two miles and are continued to the line by a succession of isolated stony kopjes, on one of which is a Turkish post.The valley then opens out both east and west, but most on the west, into the plain of Jurf Lankomi, in the south-west of which, under the flank of Jebel Akrad, lies the Teitad oasis. The line runs on due south descending gradually to Bueir, the most important of the stations hereabout. North of the station, about 250 yards away, are a culvert and a Turkish post ; and barracks and tanks succeed on the left hand till the station is reached, it has a sand-bagged pumping-station, some sheds and a house for the O.C. all joined up by trenches. Water carried from here supplies the underground reservoirs of Stabl Antar, Bir Nasif, and Bowat.Continuing from Bueir the railway runs on south over very flat and open country for about nine miles. Then hills close in both east and west and the line has to traverse a harrow pass and descend by a corkscrew curve to the Wadi Hamdh again, which slants in from north-east. It is proposed to reinforce 2nd Composite Force at once by bringing up Camel Corps from Medina, and Mule M.I.. from el-Ala, both to march by road.]MESOPOTAMIA.The Diipaniyah Episode.The following- account of an episode, which has hitherto remainded obscure, reaches us from the Chief Political Officer, Baghdad, and, though the events, which it relates, belong to military operations somewhat outside the sphere of this bulletin, we publish it here for its singular interest as fin illustration of racial character. " The operations on the Tigris which led to the fall of Baghdad were so rapidly executed that the Turks had barely time to withdraw the small body of troops which held the distant post of Samawah on the lower reaches oF the Euphrates. After the capture of Kut, Ahmed Bey, who was in command at Samawah, hurried northward. As he passed Diwaniyah he left behind him, under charge of the garrison, consisting of a single, gendarmerie battalion, a parly of sick, together with their gendarmerie escort, from Samawah. On the fall of Baghdad most of the Ottoman officials at Diwaniyah evacuated the town, after distributing arms among the inhabitants and the local Shabnnah to enable the place to protect itself if necessary against the tribes. As forsthc gendarmerie battalion, a difference of opinion appears to have arisen within its ranks as to the right course of action. A second lieutenant, a Circassian, by name Mohammed Hachiin Farrnkh, held,according to his own account, that they should remain until the Turks could relieve them, and on the ground that those, who.wished to withdraw were traitors, he caused the Commanding Officer to be hanged and he shot with his own hand two other-officers. Nevertheless, the greater part of the battalion left Diwaniyah and made its way north, and it is possible that Mohammed Effendi might have done the same if he had been aware that the British were already in occupation of Fallujah ; but no authentic account of the military situation reached him and he continued to expect the speedy return of the Turks. He was left with about sixty men, some of them Turks, the rest Russian Mohammedan subjects from the Caucasus who had been taken prisoners early in the war and had accepted service in the Sultan's army. They occupied a warehouse and an adjoining caravanserai on the bank of the Euphrates. It was an advantageous position, for the walls of the warehouse were stout and the rooms high, enabling the garrison to dominate the low buildings of the town which they could bomb at pleasure. A deep trench were cut by them down to the river bank to enable them to obtain their water-supply. Apart from Mohammed Effencli's force, there were a. Sanitary Corps not under his command and a few Turkish wounded in the Serai, a building in the middle of the town. The wounded men gave themselves up to us in the middle of July and the Sanitary Corps in the beginning of August.The townsfolk of Diwaniyah, fearing equally the tribes beyond their gates and the Turkish garrison entrenched within their limits, begged early in May that a representative of the British Government might be appointed to them, and the administration be taken over by us. In the middle of May a number oF the principal tribal sheikhs of the district came in to Baghdad to pay their respects, and being informed that, a, Government representative could not be sent them until they had expelled their guests, they undertook on then" return to Diwaniyah to put an end to Mohammed Effendi's resistance. This, however, proved to be a more difficult matter than they anticipated. Mohammed Effendi defended himself with such success that his opponents gave up the attempt to dislodge him and declared that they could do nothing against him without guns.Early in June Salih Effendi Milli, an Arab resident of Baghdad who had been Mutessarif of Diwaniyah some years ago under the Turks, was appointed A.P.O. As long, however, as Mohammed Effendi held out it was not feasible for Salih to take up his duties at Diwaniyah ; he therefore remained at Dagharah until the atmosphere cleared. In reply to a communication which he sent at this time to Mohammed Effendi, calling upon him to surrender, the latter demanded that he and his men should be allowed to return with their arms to the Turkish forces and be given a sum of money to cover the expenses of the journey.Meantime an assurance had been obtained from the Russian -Military Authorities that any Russian subjects in Yuzbashi Mohaniiued's detachment should, on surrender, be guaranteed against punishment for bearing arms with the Turks. This promise was conveyed to Mohammed Effendi through the A.P.O. at Hillah (a British Officer) by the hand of an Arab officer -of Shabanah ; but Mohammed Effencli refused to surrender except to British soldiers, on the plea that the Shabanah officer would not be able to protect him from the vengeance of the tribes who had suffered losses during the course of the hostilities.The position was increasingly unsatisfactory. There Avas a universal desire in the town and district that Mohammed Effendi should be removed. Local politicians were unable to understand why so small a force should not be dealt with summarily by ourselves, and drew from the circumstance conclusions un-favourable to us. His presence was a source of irritation and disturbance in the town and among the tribes, who were growing more and more restless, and it not only delayed the arrival of Salih Effendi, who, as above explained, had to remain at Dagharah, but also prevented the effective assumption of control of the Hillah Diwaniyah road by the Hillah Shabanah police, so that trade was at a standstill and a general feeling of uncertainty and unrest prevailed.in July the General Staff wrote to Mohammed Effendi intimating that we were prepared to send a British escort to take his surrender, but Mohammed still maintained his refusal to surrender except, to force majeure in the shape of regular troops, and although desertions among his Turkish followers has reduced his numbers to some thirty-three men, his attitude became more confident, as well as more truculent, with the lapse of time. He now no longer thought it necessary to remain within the walls of his warehouse, but appeared openly in the streets of the town. The population lived in terror of the bombs which Tie did not hesitate to use if they showed any opposition to his orders. Provisions lie obtained by bartering military stores with which he was well supplied. Early in August he tried to open negotiations with the powerful sheikhs of the Ehazahl, doubtless in the hope that they could be induced to give him a safe conduct to Ajeimi's camp ; but the KhazaMl sheikhs, who have suffered bitterly for the last twenty years at the hands of the Ottoman government and are perhaps more consistently anti-Turkish than any other tribesmen on the Euphrates, handed the letter to the Civil Commissioner.It was undesirable to allow this state of affairs to continue. On August 27, a couple of aeroplanes were sent to bomb MohamniecVs detachment, and though no casualties were caused, the effect was prompt. lie and his men, numbering twenty-eight, forthwith surrendered on. August 29, to the officials of the town. Salih Effendi appeared on the scene on. the following day, was received with acclamation as British representative and sent up the prisoners to Hillah whence they were conveyed to Baghdad.Mohammed Effendi, a fine upstanding man about forty years of age, stated that Ids prolonged resistance was due to the fact that he had constantly received news of Turkish successes from casual Arab informants and was under the impression that he was certain to be relieved. Moreover he held it to be beneath his dignity to surrender to townsmen or tribesmen and was doubt-less confirmed in this view by his fear lest they should exact retribution from him for the casualties for which he had been responsible. The British aeroplanes, however,convinced him that Ave Avere determined to put an end to the business and were in a position to carry out this resolve, and he lost no time in giving himself up. Me put the final touch of coined)' to the whole episode by offering to serve either ourselves or the Sherif in any capacity. He said, (though his reasoning will scarcely be accepted by ethnologists) that as a. Circassian he was of good Arab descent and traced his lineage to the Quraish, a, circumstance which made him the more willing to carry his sword to the Sherif. He observed, that, in any case, lie woidd be likely to fare ill at Turkish hands, since it was improbable that the relations of the Turkish officers whom he had shot would accept his plea of military duty in full atonement for his action. His offer was not accepted and lie has been treated like any other prisoner of war and sent to India and his remarkable career as a. fighting man has been brought temporarily to a, close. It may be noted that he was with the Turkish troops when the)' attacked Kerbela. in 1916. He has a wile and children at Ismid and married another wife, an Arab girl, while he was at Sainawah. She, with her immediate relations, was with Mohammed at Diwaniyah, and he was anxious to he allower! to take her to India." Affairs at Kerbela. -The Chief Political Officer, Baghdad, scuds the following statement of the situation at Kerbela in September last."Itwill be remembered that the town of Kerbela has suffered at the hands of the Turks more acutely than any other part of the Iraq during the course of the war. In May 1915, a month after the battle of Shidaibah, the Ottoman Government made an ineffectual effort to re-establish its somewhat relaxed authority in the two holy cities, on the plea that they were harbouring deserters. On that occasion the brunt of the attack was borne by Nejef ; but Kerbela also succeeded in gaining a. partial independence. The townsmen were led by a local sheikhly family, the Beit Kamunah, represented by two brothers Mohammed, Ali and Fakhri ed-Din, who arc men of very considerable wealth and influence. They arc related to the ruling house of Persia, their grandmother having been a daughter of bath Ah Shah. But the position of Iverbela was still very precarious ; for, though it was for the moment united against the Turks, it was threatened by the jealousy of the big tribal sheikhs of the neighbourhood, especially the Beni Hasan under the two brothers U in van and Alwan, sons of Saadun, who might at any time join the Turks in an active offensive.Accordingly, in October 1915, Mohammed Ali entered into communication with Sir Percy Cox, then at Kut. and after a. preliminary exchange of letters, proposed lliat we should undertake lo make him hereditary and autonomous ruler of a sacred province extending from Samarra to Nejef. We were at the time, engaged in the advance which preceded the battle of Ctesiphon, and it seemed probable that we might shortly be in close touch with Kerbela. The C.P.O. sent Mohammed Ali a friendly but colourless answer together with a small present in money for which he expressed effusive gratitude. There for Hie time the matter dropped, our withdrawal from Ctesiphon having changed the political outlook. We remained, however, in communication with Mohammed Ali and from time to time sent him money to assist him in retaining his adherents and maintaining his position at Kerbela.In April 19.1.(! the Turks made a, second and more determined effort to subdue: Kerbela. Accusing fakhri ed-Din of having stirred up the Yasar sheikhs to aid the townsmen against the Beni Hasan, they surrounded his house and arrested him. Thereupon the town rose and after a, sharp contest drove out the Turks and established an administration under the Kaiiiunali brothers. Mohammed Ali, who continued to be in communication with ourselves, repeatedly expressed his fear of the return of the Turks and begged for assistance against them. The well-grounded anxiety of the holy towns continued until the fall of Baghdad. A few days after that event Mohammed Ali came in to see the C.P.O. and after a short stay in Baghdad returned home with a mandate to maintain order until such time as it was possible for us to deal specifically with Kerbela affairs.Short of the appointment of a British officer with an adequate personal guard, a course which at the time was not feasible on military grounds, this was the only practicable alternative ; but before many weeks had passed it became evident that the arrange-ment was not wholly satisfactory to the town. The Kamunah Zadah were said to be using their privileged position to pursue their own schemes, and a growing dissatisfaction was apparent among the other town sheikhs, chief among them the Awwad family, represented by Abdul Kerim el-Awwad, a man much more typically Arab than the Kamunah. He would possibly have more influence in the town than they, but for the disadvantage that he is poor. Although the Kamunah were no doubt making-hay during a period of sunshine, there does not appear to have been much justification for serious complaint, and on the whole Mohammed Ali ran the administration Avell and kept the town quiet. But from the point, of view of the British authorities there was a more serious grievance against the brothers. A brisk traffic in supplies with the enemy was started from Kerbela,. Large caravans were reported to have come both from Damascus and Aleppo to seek foodstuffs, and the Turkish force on the Euphrates received constant supplies. The men of the Kubeisah oasis took a lively part in these enterprises. While Fahad Bey ibn Hadhdhal was at Baghdad in June, a. large Syrian caravan arrived on the outskirts of Kerbela and began openly to load up. Fahad Bey at our request sent word to his son, Mahrut, to. stop these proceedings ; the goods which had already been purchased were seized and brought in to his estate at Ghazazah. The owners were finally obliged to sell them and depart empty. After Fahad Bey's agreement with us the transmission of goods by way of the desert was to some extent stopped, but with the connivance of the Kamunah the trade continued furtively along the Euphrates, through Mas'ud and Jannabiyin country, where Fahad Bey had not yet established control.It was impossible that - the Kamunah Zadah could be ignorant of what was going on. There was indeed abundant evidence to the contrary. Of Mohammed Ali the best that could be said was that he passively connived in the traffic, while Fakhri was an active participant. The town police, whom Mohammed Ali, as representative of the Government, had in his employment, were used to escort safely out of the town goods destined for the enemy, and two retainers of the Kamunah Zadah were accustomed to sign the necessary passes. Cloth, rice, wheat and coffee were the favourite exports. While the large profits to be derived from the levy of fees of jfel. and even 2 on each loaded camel were probably sufficient in themselves to explain the Kainunahs' behaviour, it is also possible that they had come to realise that under British ride their grandiose personal ambitions stood small chance of materialising and they were inclined to listen to the voice of the tempter. The Turks were undoubtedly carrying on extensive propaganda among the Euphrates tribes, coupled with promises of autonomy when the Iraq should be restored to the Porte. Humours of a rapprochement between Fakhri and the Beni Hasan sheikhs. Formerly so hostile to the town sheikhs of Kerbela, and of mm-municacions between him and Ajil ibn Samarmad, the powerful Sheikh of the Zubeid who has not yet made submission, were nor, reassuring. In any case, supply to the Turkish troops on the Euphrates could not be permitted to continue.On September 7, the Civil Commissioner summoned Fakhri to present himself at Baghdad on the 9th. He complied immediately, and on his arrival it was explained to him that his undoubted participation in and encouragement of trade with the enemy, had made his presence in Kerbela incompatible with military interests and that he would be sent to India, as an officer prisoner of war. He accepted with resignation a decision which , could scarcely have been unforeseen by him. The following da)' Mohammed Ali also received a verbal summons from the Civil Commissioner, through the Intelligence Officer at Kerbefa, to come to Baghdad. He expressed himself willing to leave next morning, but subsequently, having received news of Fakhri's internment, he declined to go, though given hud/i wa hakht (assurance of personal safety) by the Intelligence Officer. The Civil Commissioner therefore despatched to him a, letter by the hand of the Nawab Mohammed Husein Qizilbash, an Indian subject and a well known inhabitant of Kerbela,, who has been, since the occupation, employed in the Political Office in Baghdad, explaining the reasons for the action taken with regard to Fakhri and adding that since, in view of what had happened, it was not considered in the interests of the administration that Mohammed Ali should continue to act, as Government Agent, a. British Officer had been appointed A.P.O. If Mohammed Ali under existing circumstances preferred to retire from Kerbela, the Government would make arrangements for his residence in comfort in some other place or town in the Iraq to be agreed upon.After some hesitation Mohammed Ali agreed to obey the original summons and come in to Baghdad. In this decision lie-was largely swayed by the advice of Sheikh Husein Mazandarani, the leading Mujtahid of Kerbela,, who urged him strongly not to disobey the orders of the Civil Commissioner, at the same time reminding him that the British Government, in no way resembled the Ottoman, and that promises of security given by us might safely be trusted. The part played by the leading Mnjtahid of Nejef, Seyyid Mohammed Kadhim Vazdi, who is the most revered of the Shiah Ulema of the Iraq, was not less satisfactory. In reply to an appeal from Mohammed Ali to intervene on behalf of Fakhri, he said that he had long since retired from the world; if they wished for his opinion on the Word of God he was pre-pared to give it, but he would not express any view on affairs of state. Incidentally he observed that he had no intention of declaring a Jihad against aeroplanes and motors. He consented, however, to put in a plea that the office of Kiliddar, lately held by Fakhri, might not be removed from the family. For the present Mohammed Albs son, Hamid, has been left in charge.Mohammed Ali is now in Baghdad, staying with the Naqib, who, at the CCs request, kindly invited him to be his guest until a house could be got ready for him. Ultimately he will probably elect to take up his abode in Kadhimein. He arrived in time to see his brother Fakhri before the latter left for Basrah and India. By a curious coincidence Fakhri has as his companion on the voyage Mohammed Effcndi, the officer of gendarmerie who recently surrendered at Diwauiyah. The last occasion of their meeting wa,s in 1916, when Mohammed was with the Turkish troops which attacked Kerbela. The conjunction though entirely fortuitous is conducive to salutary reflections.Major Pulley is installed as A.P.O. at Kerbela and the town is perfectly quiet. According to private information volunteered by one of the Ulema of Kerbela, who has arrived at Baghdad, the religious heads of the Kerbela community are highly delighted with the removal of the Kanninah brothers, with whom, for the sake of their personal immunity from molestation, they have been obliged to keep on outwardly cordial terms, though the truculent Kamunah excesses and oppression have been a continual source of anxiety. The support, which the authority of the Adminis-tration has had in this matter from the leading Mujtahids, both at Nejef and Kerbela, has been a, matter for extreme satisfaction."ABYSSINIA.We are still without news of. further developments at Adds Abeba later than what has already been reported (see p. 434) ; but more details of the causes which have led to the foreshadowed crisis have come to hand.The position of the Empress is not in question. Having once been crowned, she will probably remain on the throne for her lifetime. She cannot, however, as a woman, exercise personally the supreme power in Abyssinia and must content herself with acting through a representative who thus becomes the actual head of the Government. For the past year this position has been occupied by lias Taffari in his quality of Heir Apparent, and it is only of late that his right to this position has been in any way called in question, although the Council of Ministers have always maintained that his decisions ought to be referred to them for sanction before being carried into effect. So long as Fitaurari Hapta Giorgis was at the capital all went smoothly enough ; but, on his departure and after the fall of Bituaded Haili Giorgis, the leadership of the council passed to Dejaz Igazu who at once began to intrigue with the Empress against Ras Taffari with the idea of getting all the power into his own hands. It was an easy matter for him to persuade the Empress that the Ras was exceeding his powers and was reducing her to the position of a mere puppet on the throne and, at the same time, to spread the rumour that Ras Taffari was selling his country to the Europeans, thereby creating a hostile atmosphere among the lesser officers and ignorant soldiery and preparing the way for a coup aV&tat.The execution of the plot was timed for Mascal, the principal religious feast of the year, when the national and religious feelings of the population can most easily be stirred, and Dejaz Igazu counted on the support of his god-father, Ras Demisie, and of the Mahal Safari, the latter being a composite body of some 30,000 men made up of the imperial bodyguard and of all the servants, artizans and hangers-on in the palace, ancl dependent solely on the Emperor of the time. Ras Taffari, by ordering, as already reported, Ras Demisie to proceed at once to his country, by collecting in Adis Abeba 5,000 of his Harrar army, and by granting a district in the Arussi to the Mahal Safari, succeeded for the moment in disorganizing the plot and the feast of Mascal seems to have passed off quietly.The main point remains however untouched, and the question for the future is whether Ras . Taffari or Dejaz Igazu is to exercise the powers of government under the Empress. While it is probable that Ras Taffari must win in the end, there is no denying that Dejaz Igazu has for the moment many points in his favour. The Empress tacitly supports him, and his followers are concentrated in the Ghebi, while the adherents of" the Ras, as well as his troops, are scattered in the town. Taffari himself, however, is obliged to live in the Ghebi ; if Dejaz Igazu, therefore, ever feels himself strong enough, it would be an easy matter to arrest and chain Taffari up before airy support could reach him. It is doubtful that Dejaz Igazu would dare to attempt such a stroke now that the strength of the rival parties is fairly evenly balanced, and probably no decision will be come to until Fitaurari Hapta Giorgis returns to Adis Abeba. If no incident occurs before then to precipitate a crisis, it is believed that the Ras intends to make the Fitaurari Bituaded and Prime Minister with full powers to re-organize the govern-ment ; and. the first step to this end would probably be the dissolution of' the Council of Ministers a measure which would put an end to Dejaz Igazu's influence. NOTES.Telcfit.The news of General Maude's capture of Tekrit, the birthplace of the great Saladin, is only less welcome than that of the occupation of Gaza and most of southern Palestine by General Allenby. Tekrit is the northern frontier town of the Baghdad district on the Mesopotamian bank of the Tigris and the last settlement of any importance on either bank for over 100 miles as one ascends the river. Beyond it, on the northward road, lies almost continuous steppe desert, with rare spring or well water, as far as Shura, the first real village, which is less than thirty miles south of Mosul. Qalah Sherghat, the ancient Asshur, where a German expedition has been excavating for nearly twenty years, lies over sixty miles above Tekrit. It has been developed by the Germano-Turk command into a considerable road-station, but, like all the Tekrit-Mosul road, it can be harried by the Jerba Shamihar from el-Hadr, and is surrounded by desert. We can now close the caravan track from Tekrit to Hit, which has been developed of late by the Turks, and they can only open another, and considerably longer one (over 100 miles) from Hit to Qalah Sherghat by conciliating or terrorising the Shammar. The Duleim, hitherto their allies, also range in these parts. Tekrit itself is a place of some 5,000 inhabitants, who live of. their. gardens and the profits of rafting trade downstream and the ferry to the left bank of the Tigris. They have numerous primitive river-craft. In the wars of the 11th to the 13th century armies often chose Tekrit as their point of passage.More about Shahturs.Later Intelligence Summaries from the Mesopotamian Expeditionary Force supplement the information given on p. 422. It appears that Birejik is building shahturs in great numbers, though Jerablus is still the general assembling yard. They are towed back by man power, after finishing their trip, a deserter having seen forty a day being dragged up stream. On September 2, there were seventy-five pairs of ordinary shahturs in the yard at Jerablus, and also four designed to carry especially heavy weights. An agent, considered " fairly reliable," states that he left Jerablus on September 2, in a convoy of twenty-five shahturs carrying 250 infantry, ammunition, supplies and entrenching tools. They reached Hit on September 19. Von Miicke is said to be now at Meskineh.
